Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2010 12:09PM scrapmom40 wrote: Here is a short description that I found on the internet. Lymphovascular Invasion Breast cancers have a blood supply like normal tissue and organs. Tumors also have lymphatic channels running through them, which serve as a circulatory system in the body for tissue fluid and proteins separate from the blood circulation. If cancer cells under the microscope appear to invade into the blood vessels or lymphatic channels of the tumor, the possibility that cancer cells have spread to the lymph nodes or other areas in the body increases. This is called lymphovascular invasion or LVI. I also had LVI when I was diagnosed back in 2008.  Because of the LVI, I had 4 rounds of AC chemo.  I did not have lymph node involvement.  I had a SNB with 3 nodes removed.  All three nodes were clear.  Good Luck!
Posts.Title: Lymph-Vascular Invasion lalalara lalalara

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2009 05:41PM scrapmom40 wrote: Angel - I have not been following your story (since I don't come on the board very often), but I wanted to reply to your question "If anyone knows why it wouldn't show up on US".  There are 3 modalities that are used to find breast lumps or other things going on in the breast (1-Mammogram, 2-Ultrasound, and 3-MRI).  My lump did not show up on Mammogram and did not show up on the MRI, but did show on Ultrasound.  Since me, and my doctors could clearly feel the lump, after they did a mammogram, but could not see the lump, they did an ultrasound.  Most people will say the MRI is the best, but because I have dense breast tissue my lump did not show on MRI either.  So in my case, ultrasound was the best but that is not true for all.  There are many women who have BC and it did not show up in mammogram or possibly U/S or MRI.  That is why they typically do more than one test, especially when they can clearly feel a lump.  I don't know if that helps you, but just wanted to let you know that it is not uncommon for one test to fail.  I hope you get answers soon and I will be hoping the answer is B9. Take care of yourself. Karen

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2010 06:13PM scrapmom40 wrote: Hi Orange - unfortunately, I don't really have any help for you, but I just wanted to say I think it is impossible to find a mastectomy bra that is padded.  The manufacturer makes them so the prostheses can go in either side.  I had a prostheses and was also an A cup.  Before BC I wore padded bras (not crazy padded, but padded).  I hated that I could not get a mastectomy bra that had some padding for my natural breast.  It would be nice if some bra company would make them so they catered to either the left or the right side so you could get some padding on your natural breast.  I don't think it exists.  I looked and was never able to find anything.  Plus, I found the mastectomy bras to have too much material.  I have since had my other breast removed and had reconstruction surgery so I can wear regular bras again.  Good luck in your search.  I hope you are able to find something that is comfortable and makes you feel pretty! Take care, Karen

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2010 12:54PM scrapmom40 wrote: Veronica - I had the BRCA test done when I was diagnosed.  They way it works (at least as far as my doctor told me) is they draw your blood and send it out to Myriad.  Myriad then contacts your insurance agency to see how much of the cost of the test they will cover.  Then you will get a phone call stating your insurance is going to pay for the whole test with no cost to you, they are only going to pay half and you pay the other half, etc. etc.  Once they call you and tell you how much you have to pay out-of-pocket then you tell them either to continue with the test, or don't continue with the test (say if insurance isn't going to cover it at all and you can't afford to pay the $3,000+ yourself).   We just covered this topic with a Doctor this week at my BC Support Group.  If you come back positive, then any other family members that need to be tested can be tested for a few hundred dollars (instead of the full amount) because then they only have to look at the specific gene.  (And yes you are correct about prostate cancer also having to do with the BRCA 1 and BRCA 2 gene). I would assume if you meet with a genetic counselor they would agree that you are a good candidate to be tested based on your family history and they could write it up in such a way to get you the most coverage possible for the test. Good luck!  I hope you are able to be tested and that insurance covers you 100%.  Karen

Posts.Content: scrapmom40 wrote: I am wondering if anyone has experienced bleeding or their period during chemo?   I am getting AC chemo every two weeks.  My first treatment went perfectly fine.   In the week after my second treatment, I got what I thought was my period.   It was on schedule so although I thought I was not going to get my period during chemo, since the timing was right, I just assumed I had my period.   Well I had my third treatment last Sunday (one week ago), and I started bleeding again yesterday like I have my period again (which would not be normal at all since my periods are pretty regular).  I called the doctor on call and he did not seem to alarmed.   I will call my doctor tomorrow (since today is Sunday), but I am a little nervous and not sure why I would be bleeding.  Wondering if anyone else has experienced some bleeding during chemo.   Please let me know. Thanks.  Karen (scrapmom40) Karen Dx 1/31/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2012 02:36PM scrapmom40 wrote: I had AC treatment (Adriamycin and Cytoxan (sp??) and I lost the hair on my head, but did not lose my eyebrows or my eyelashes.  I lost pretty much all the hair on my body except for those 2 places.  I assume it had something to do with maybe they don't grow at a rapid pace like the hair on your head does, or your legs, etc.   Hopefully you won't lose your eyebrows and eyelashes either.  I will keep my fingers crossed for you.  Good luck with your treatment. Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2008 01:18PM scrapmom40 wrote: Hi Sammie - I am also a 41 year old mother of 2 (2 boys ages 13 and 9).   I was diagnosed with Breast Cancer last January.  I found a lump, but my lump did not go away when my cycle ended.  I had read on line to wait through 1 cycle since it could just be a cyst and could go away.  Mine did not go away and did turn out to be cancer.   I did not have any other symptoms like dimpling of the breast or discharge or anything (probably because it was Stage 1 and not advanced).   Any way, you should definitely get it checked out.  Mine did not show up on Mammogram or MRI and only showed on ultrasound.  I hope that it turns out to be nothing, but please get it checked out.   If it turns out to be something, the earlier the doctors find it and treat it the better off you will be.  Good Luck and let us know how you make out. Karen

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2009 12:32PM scrapmom40 wrote: I chickened out the first time I was to have my MRI.  I just couldn't do it.  I had to reschedule my appointment.  When I went back, they gave me a prescription for Ativan so I took that before I went and they let my husband stay in the room with me and he was able to hold my hand the entire time the test was being done.  Since then, I have had 2 other MRI's and I have been able to make it through the test without the Ativan and without my husband being in the room with me (I hate the idea of exposing him to any radiation, etc.).  I just keep my eyes closed.  It stinks!  Hopefully you can find an Open MRI machine or a larger one so you don't feel so closed in.  Good Luck!!
